Angles

1. Measuring & labeling angles

Labelling angles

Consider the following diagram.

Which of the following is the most correct name for the marked angle?

Answer:
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

Trace over the angle with your finger, and label the angle in that order. If there is only one angle at a point, you can use that point label.

STEP: Label the angle
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

We indicate an angle either with a ∧∧ above the point where the angle is formed, or with a ∠∠ in front of the point labels.

There are two different angles at Point UU, so if we just write Û U^, it will be unclear which angle we mean.

To make sure that we are understood, we have to label the marked angle with three points, either VÛ WVU^W or WÛ VWU^V. If you trace your finger over the points in this order, you will draw the angle.

Submit your answer as:

Estimating acute angles

The diagram below shows two rays: TT and SS. They form an acute angle, which is shaded yellow.

Estimate the size of the angle. Select your answer from the drop down box.

Answer: The angle is approximately .
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]
Use the xx and yy-axis lines shown to help with your estimation. Remember that those axes have a 90°90° angle between them.
STEP: Draw in a line at 45°45° to help estimate the angle
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

For this question we need to estimate the size of the angle between the lines in the diagram. We can know immediately that the angle must be greater than zero degrees but less than 9090 degrees.

It can be helpful to draw a line exactly in between the xx and yy-axes, as shown below. That line sits at 45°45° (half of 90°90°). By comparing to that line and the two axes, we can get a pretty good idea of the angle between lines TT and SS. The angle here is quite close to the halfway line. That means the angle must be close to 45°45°. The best choice in the list is 48°48°.

The correct option from the list of choices is 48° .

Estimating reflex angles

The reflex angle at the intersection of rays ZZ and YY is shown below by the green area.

Estimate the size of the angle. Select your answer from the drop down box.

Answer: The angle is approximately .
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]
Remember reflex angles are always less than 360°360° but more than 180°180°.
STEP: Use the axes of the Cartesian plane to estimate the angle
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

We need to estimate the size of the angle in the diagram. It is a reflex angle: a reflex angle is an angle greater than 180°180° but less than 360°360°.

It is helpful to draw in the axes on the Cartesian plane to help estimate the angle in the question. The axis pointing to the left sits at 180°180°. The axis pointing down sits at 270°270°. We can also consider the dashed lines, which show the angles passing through the middle of Quadrants 3 and 4.

By comparing the angle to the reference lines on the Cartesian plane we can make a good estimation of the angle.

The angle size = 253°253°.

Estimating angles and identifying angle types

Two rays are shown on the figure below. The rays meet at a common point and the shaded area indicates an angle between the rays. The dashed lines are perpendicular reference lines.

Answer the two questions below about the angle.

TIP: Use the perpendicular reference lines to help yourself.
Answer:
  1. What is the approximate measure of the shaded angle?
  2. What type of angle is represented here?
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

Based on the reference lines, is the angle greater than or less than 90°90°? Is it greater than or less than 180°180°?

STEP: Compare the angle to the reference lines to estimate the angle
[−1 point ⇒ 1 / 2 points left]

An angle is the amount of turn between two straight lines that have a common end point. In this question we need to estimate the angle in the diagram (which is represented by the shaded arc). The picture below shows how we can estimate the angle. Each of the quadrants in the image is 90°90°. We have labelled them as multiples of 90°90° starting with 0°0° at the position of the first arrow.

We can begin by counting these 90°90° blocks. Then we can add on the last, smaller rotation. In this case, there is a single 90°90° rotation. For the remaining part of the angle, we can see that it is significantly further than halfway through that quadrant. That means the angle is something like 70°70° or 75°75°. To get the total estimated angle, we just need to add everything together: the answer should be close to 90°+70°=160∘90°+70°=160∘.

The best choice on the list is 170°.

STEP: Identify the type of angle
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

We also need to identify the type of angle in the figure. The choices in the list correspond to different sizes of angles. For example, an acute angle is an angle which is less than 90°90° and a reflex angle is an angle which is greater than 180°180° and less than 360°360°.

The correct choice for the type of angle is: Obtuse angle.

Submit your answer as: and

Labelling angles

Consider the following diagram.

Which of the following is the most correct name for the marked angle?

Answer:
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

At what point and number is the marked angle?

STEP: Label the angle
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

When angles are labelled with numbers, we can use these to easily refer to the angle. You can tell these small numbers aren't the sizes of the angles, as they are not labelled with degree signs (and they are much too small).

There are four different angles at Point TT, so if we just write T̂ T^ it will be unclear which angle we mean, because there is more than one angle at Point TT.

To make sure that we are understood, we can use the point label (TT) and the relevant number (11) to label the angle as T̂ 1T^1.

NOTE: It would also be correct to label the angle as PT̂ QPT^Q. However, we don't label angles as PT̂ 1QPT^1Q, because it is not necessary to use both the angle number and all three point labels.
Submit your answer as:

Estimating obtuse angles

The diagram below shows two rays: ZZ and YY. They form an obtuse angle, which is shaded red.

Estimate the size of the angle. Select your answer from the drop down box.

Answer: The angle is approximately .
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

Use the xx and yy-axis lines shown to help with your estimation. Remember that those axes have a 90°90° angle between them.

STEP: Draw in lines at 45°45° and 135°135° to help estimate the angle
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

For this question we need to estimate the size of the angle between the lines in the diagram. We can know immediately that the angle must be greater than 9090 degrees but less than 180180 degrees. This is because the angle is big enough to pass the yy-axis but not big enough to make a straight line.

It is helpful to draw lines exactly in between the xx and yy-axes, as shown below. Those lines sit 45°45° from the axes themselves (half of 90°90°). So the new line on the left is at 135°135°. By comparing to that line and the two axes, we can get a pretty good idea of the angle between lines ZZ and YY. The angle here is definitely larger than 135°135°, but not by much. A good estimate is something around 145°145°. The best choice on the list is 147°147°.

The correct choice from the list is 147°.

Submit your answer as:

Types of angles at an intersection

The diagram shows line IJIJ intersecting line EFEF. The intersecting lines create four different angles. These angles are labelled with variables α,β,δ,α,β,δ, and xx.

Which angle or angles are adjacent to angle xx?

Answer: The angles adjacent to angle xx are: .
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

You might need to look up the answers in your notes. You need to figure out the meaning of 'adjacent' angles.

STEP: Determine which angle or angles are adjacent to xx
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

This question is about angles at an intersection of two lines. Here are three important defintions for angles in this situation:

  • Adjacent angles: angles that are next to each other.
  • Supplementary angles: angles with a sum of 180°180°; supplementary angles make a straight line.
  • Vertically opposite angles: angles which share a vertex and are opposite from each other; vertically opposite angles are on opposite sides of a vertex.

In this case we need to identify the angles (or the angle) which are adjacent to angle xx. So we must find any angles which are next to angle xx. There are two such neighbours: angles ββ and δδ.

The correct answer choice is: ββ and δδ.

Submit your answer as:

Exercises

Labelling angles

Consider the following diagram.

Which of the following is the most correct name for the marked angle?

Answer:
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

Trace over the angle with your finger, and label the angle in that order. If there is only one angle at a point, you can use that point label.

STEP: Label the angle
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

We indicate an angle either with a ∧∧ above the point where the angle is formed, or with a ∠∠ in front of the point labels.

There are two different angles at Point DD, so if we just write ∠D∠D, it will be unclear which angle we mean.

To make sure that we are understood, we have to label the marked angle with three points, either ∠CDB∠CDB or ∠BDC∠BDC. If you trace your finger over the points in this order, you will draw the angle.

Estimating angles and identifying angle types

Two rays are shown on the figure below. The rays meet at a common point and the shaded area indicates an angle between the rays. The dashed lines are perpendicular reference lines.

Answer the two questions below about the angle.

TIP: Use the perpendicular reference lines to help yourself.
Answer:
  1. What is the approximate measure of the shaded angle?
  2. What type of angle is represented here?
HINT: <no title>

For the remaining part of the angle, we can see that it is a bit more than halfway through the quadrant. So the angle must be close to 50°50° or 55°55°. To get the total estimated angle, we just need to add everything together: the answer should be close to 180°+55°=235∘180°+55°=235∘.

Types of angles at an intersection

The diagram shows line IJIJ intersecting line EFEF. The intersecting lines create four different angles. These angles are labelled with variables α,β,δ,α,β,δ, and xx.

Which angle or angles are vertically opposite to angle xx?

Answer: The angles vertically opposite to angle xx are: .
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

You might need to look up the answers in your notes. You need to figure out the meaning of 'vertically opposite' angles.

STEP: Determine which angle or angles are vertically opposite to xx
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

This question is about angles at an intersection of two lines. Here are three important defintions for angles in this situation:

  • Adjacent angles: angles that are next to each other.
  • Supplementary angles: angles with a sum of 180°180°; supplementary angles make a straight line.
  • Vertically opposite angles: angles which share a vertex and are opposite from each other; vertically opposite angles are on opposite sides of a vertex.

In this case we need to identify the angles (or the angle) which are vertically opposite to angle xx. That means we need the angle which is across the vertex from xx. There is only one angle across the vertex from xx, which is angle αα only.

The correct answer choice is: αα only.

Intersections of straight lines

In the diagram below, TUTU and VWVW are straight lines.

Determine the size of pp, giving a reason for your answer.

Answer: p=p= °° (())
numeric
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

Remember the facts that you have learned about straight lines, and think about which one would be useful here. Straight line facts:

  1. Adjacent angles on a straight line add up to 180°180° (adj ∠∠s on a str line).
  2. Vertically opposite angles are equal (vert opp ∠∠s).
  3. Angles around a point add up to 360°360° (∠∠s round a pt).
STEP: Determine the size of pp and give a reason
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

The diagram contains straight lines, so a good starting point is to remember all of the facts that we know about straight lines, and think about which one would be useful here.

  1. Adjacent angles on a straight line add up to 180°180° (adj ∠∠s on a str line).
  2. Vertically opposite angles are equal (vert opp ∠∠s).
  3. Angles around a point add up to 360°360° (∠∠s round a pt).

TUTU and VWVW are straight lines, which means that they form vertically opposite angles when they intersect. These vertically opposite angles are equal. Therefore

p=51°+50°=101°p=51°+50°=101°
.

In geometry, it is as important to give a reason for your answer as it is to find the size of the angle. We know that pp is equal to 101°101° because of vertically opposite angles. The accepted abbreviation for this reason is vert opp ∠∠s.

So p=101°p=101° (vert opp ∠∠s).

35°+90°+x∴x=180°(∠s on a str line)=55°35°+90°+x=180°(∠s on a str line)∴x=55°

In the same way, all of the angles below BCBC add up to 180°180°:

77°+44°+19°+y∴y=180°(∠s on a str line)=40°77°+44°+19°+y=180°(∠s on a str line)∴y=40°

Here is the completed diagram, with all of the angle values labelled:

The angles in a full turn (revolution) must add up to 360°360°. This is a good way to check our answers:

35°+90°+55°+77°+44°+19°+40°=360°35°+90°+55°+77°+44°+19°+40°=360°

y=40°y=40°

∴y∴y is an acute angle (less than 90°°).

Straight line facts:

  2. Vertically opposite angles are equal (vert opp ∠∠s).
  3. Angles around a point add up to 360°360° (∠∠s round a pt).
STEP: Determine the size of cc
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

PQPQ and RSRS are straight lines, which means that they form vertically opposite angles when they intersect. These vertically opposite angles are equal.

In geometry, it is as important to give a reason for your answer as it is to find the size of the angle. We know that cc is equal to 112°112° because the angles are vertically opposite. The accepted abbreviation for this reason is vert opp ∠∠s.

So c=112°c=112° (vert opp ∠∠s).

We can see that ∠PSM∠PSM is vertically opposite the 100°100° angle.

∠PSM=100°(vert opp ∠s)∠PSM=100°(vert opp ∠s)

Calculate angles between parallel lines

In the diagram below, EF∥EF∥ GHGH. JKJK is a transversal.

NOTE: A transversal is a line that cuts across two other lines.

What is the value of xx?

Answer: x=x= °°
numeric
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]
STEP: <no title>
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

Co-interior angles are both inside the parallel lines, on the same side of the transversal. If we highlight the angles we will see a "U" shape. This helps us to identify co-interior angles.

Since we know that co-interior angles add up to 180°180°, we can write:

x+63°∴x∴x=180°(co-int ∠s,EF∥GH)=180°−63°=117°x+63°=180°(co-int ∠s,EF∥GH)∴x=180°−63°∴x=117°

Therefore x=117°x=117° (co-int ∠∠s, EF∥GHEF∥GH).

NOTE: Although you didn't need to give a reason here, reasons are important in geometry. You should learn these reasons and always write them in your work.
